Aside from his acting career, Jordan is also an entrepreneur. He is the co-founder of Higher Ground Productions, a production company focused on creating impactful storytelling through diverse voices. Jordan is committed to giving opportunities to underrepresented groups in the entertainment industry.

After graduating, Jordan moved to New York City and continued to hone his craft in off-Broadway productions.

The film, which is based on the true story of the shooting of Oscar Grant by a police officer, earned Jordan critical acclaim and numerous awards, including the Golden Globe for Best Actor in a Motion Picture, Drama.

His portrayal of Adonis "Donnie" Creed earned him the Academy Award for Best Actor, and he became the first African-American actor to win an Oscar for a lead role in a "Rocky" film.

In addition to his acting career, Jordan has been involved in the music industry, releasing two rap albums under his stage name, Mr. Moe. He has also ventured into film production, co-founding Outlier Society Productions with his father, the producer Ryan Coogler, who directed "Fruitvale Station" and "Black Panther."

Throughout his career, Jordan has been recognized for his charitable work and activism, speaking out on issues such as racial equality, police brutality, and the Black Lives Matter movement. Jordan's passion for acting began early in life, when he participated in school theater productions and local acting workshops. He attended the prestigious Northwestern University, where he majored in Theater and African American Studies. During his college years, Michael landed his first professional acting role in a short film titled "Las Vegas."
